title: Between 11 October 2019 and 12 June 2020, will the Hong Kong dollar close above HK$7.8510?
preds: It is the day before and the chance is nil

It is strange how fast the Hong Kong street protests did evaporate from western screens because the US now have street protests of their own and rightly so. I wonder how the situation is like in Hong Kong at the moment. I don't expect protesters have given up, so a tiny bit of likelyhood remains that the central bank will not be able to defend the peg until 12 June 2020. Boris Johnson kindly invited wealthy people with bank accounts in HK to resettle to the UK, after US POTUS declared the special treatment of the financial industry in the special administrative region of Hong Kong will end. If capital outflows out of HK will be fast and large enough, the peg might fall. It doesn't look like that, since the HKD is pretty stable around 7.75 HKD per USD.
Situation still developing. Confirming the forecast for now.
Increasing slightly despite the reduced time for closing this question owing to the proposal of the new national security law, which might create some possible turbulence.

I cite Anna Coren/CNN: "After this historic day, there is no more 'One Country, Two Systems' policy. It will be One Country, One System." or similar. If that holds, then Hong Kong will no longer be an important financial hub in SE-Asia, and massive outflows of financial investments in the short term could weaken the HKD vs. USD with an increased volatility.
Once the pressure of money flows is so high and the net position of foreign currency reserves at the HK central bank become so low or the rate of foreign currency reserves' depletion from keeping the peg's range reaches an unsustainable level that the local administration is forced to decide dopping the peg, we could observe an inverse "Frankenshock" with a massive devaluation of 15 to 20 per cent.
As the time span is 19 days only, events will have to accelerate very boldly for that to happen, but as of now it appears more likely than not.
The Chinese legislation on Hong Kong yesterday actually moved the needle.
Wont happen within the time period mentioned - especially for a peg that has been lasting for so long, and with a monetary authority with access to a lot of forex reserves.
$7.77 today. Not really leaping past that.
7.77 again today. Baseline for a long period not above 7.85
With US dollar strengthening and money in Asia decreasing in value with coronavirus problems it makes this less likely. Lowering.
With a strong US economy, tampering with the trade balance, the impacts of the virus, and civil unrest. I think it will be very difficult for HK to gain nearing 1% on US$.
Hong Kong needs to remain stable and not create waves by changing its currency in relation to US.
It has not been above 7.83 for a year.

From the Economist:
“Its currency has been tied to the American dollar since 1983 and confined to a narrow trading band of hk$7.75–7.85 to the dollar since 2005. If it falls to the weak side, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (hkma) is obliged to sell as many American dollars as people want to buy for hk$7.85. That has stopped the currency falling further”
“According to its defenders, Hong Kong’s currency peg is “virtually impregnable”. The hkma’s foreign-exchange reserves amount to $440bn, twice as much as the money supply, narrowly defined to include banknotes and the banks’ claims on the monetary authority. The banks would run out of Hong Kong dollars before it ran out of American ones.
Why then is it only “virtually” impregnable? For one thing, there are broader definitions of money supply. A war chest of $440bn may be large compared with banks’ deposits at the hkma. But it is small compared with customers’ deposits with banks (hk$6.9trn, equivalent to $880bn). If every depositor wanted to convert their holdings into American dollars, there would not be enough to go around.
Such conversions would also have broader economic implications. Every Hong Kong dollar sold to the monetary authority disappears. All else equal, it then becomes dearer for the banks to borrow the diminishing number of Hong Kong dollars that remain. These high interest rates make holding the currency more lucrative and short-selling it more costly. But insofar as households and firms still need to borrow in Hong Kong dollars, these high interest rates also hurt the economy. How much pain would Hong Kong be willing to take?
The peg’s downfall may be imaginable. But is it probable? One place to look is the options market, where investors can hedge against the risk of the currency moving outside the band. For about 40% of the period from June 2005 to July 2018, option prices implied that the odds of the peg breaking were above 10%, suggests a recent study by Samuel Drapeau, Tan Wang and Tao Wang of Shanghai Jiao Tong University. But for most of that time markets were betting on the currency strengthening past hk$7.75 to the dollar, not weakening past hk$7.85.“
Any one-day close will qualify; devaluation of currency is a strong possibility given continuing political and economic unrest.
Today it is 7.78. Will raise some and watch. It might go up because they are better prepared for coronovirus and some Chinese will go there and drive the value of everything up.

The HK dollar has never reached above 7.85.  Since the start of the civil unrest (February, 2019), it has reached 7.85 a few times but never breached it even at the peak of the violent demonstrations.  While the causes for the unrest has not been settled (and probably never will since China will not back down from its authoritarian ways), the violent confrontations have subsided.  It appears that the government's tactic is to wait out the protesters.  It is very unlikely that 7.851 level be breached.
I want China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and I'm hoping that the trade problems will stay their hand, but anything is possible if you are President for Life.
I believe the Chinese will eventually pull the plug on the demonstrarors and the HK Dollar will plummet.
Becoming less likely as things cool down
It has not in over a year. The riots have hurt the economy there so no it is unlikely.
Updating due to recent downward trend

From Wall Street Journal (and its currently 7.7890). I’m bumping up considerably but realize it’s still a long shot at 10%
“The Hong Kong dollar on Wednesday stood at 7.7876 against the greenback. That represented a 0.8% gain from its weakest point earlier this year. Aside from a brief period in July, the currency hasn’t traded below 7.80 per dollar since 2017.”
https://www.wsj.com/articles/hong-kong-dollar-surges-after-rough-patch-11576656123
Not until after the dust from the impending crackdown settles.
Below. Too many unresolved issues will result in lack of confidence in the political situation in HK. Breach of the take over treaty will cost China dearly in the HK markets.

Between 11 October 2019 and 12 June 2020, will the Hong Kong dollar close above HK$7.8510? 
Nov 20 2019 Bloomberg says 7.825. The currency has strengthened this month even as positions have hardened.
June is a long way out, but finance is stable even if the population is not.
Police are being shot with Bows and Arrows. Recession is official. Poison blow darts will collapse them.

Between 11 October 2019 and 12 June 2020, will the Hong Kong dollar close above HK$7.8510? Per Bloomberg Nov 7 it sits at 7.8266. Ceasation of demonstrations and return to normalicy would appear to be prerequisites to any strong advance in the HK dollar. 8 months is a long time, but I don't see policy or people in place to achieve normalicy in the short term. For now I will join the pesimests.
Revised after incorrect data used for previous prediction.

The question should specify which market (ie spot or forward market). Assuming we're talking about the spot market, it hasn't closed above 7.8510 since 1983. While stresses are building within the HKD market, theyre not sufficient to break the peg. In addition, a break of the peg would be seen as a win for the protesters, and China has an interest in not letting that happen.

I don't know if I'm misreading the question but the crowd forecast seems to be very very low. The HKD has closed over 7.851 4 times within the last eight months (once during the protests too). I think the situation is likely to improve in the timeframe in question and that makes it closing above 7.851 pretty likely in my opinion. The situation could get worse which would obviously make such an occurrence more unlikely but currently I put the chance (based on some very rough calculations on past rate occurrence) of about 60% that it will.
Mass liquidation of billions? I don't think so.
Based on reserves vs circulation which would be ~1%...combined with ramping up of hostility and Uncle Xi’s willingness to use force.

Volatile times : but the structure of the peg has evidently been resilient - if obvious factors such as riots/PRC exerting further influence on the social/political and economic future of HK - its place within the global financial market - whether it will remain a convenient hub for Asian cross border financial activity and money flows remains to be seen - the issues that are dominating the headlines do not appear likely to disappear any time soon.

Although there is no precedence for this, if the tensions in Hongkong do not abate the monetary peg will be put to the test. For now, the Hongkong government, will do whatever it takes to maintain its monetary policy.

This is my first forecast for this question, based on the outside view. I take into account two factors: (1) The current peg window has been in effect for 14 years (the peg for about 35 years, but before it didn't have a specific window)
(2) The one country two systems framework is only guaranteed till 2047 (28 years from now) For (1) I will use the "ordinary world" hypothesis, which is as follows: in the world as we know it, this state is not an ineluctable necessity (a 90 to 100% probability event) neither a strike of luck (a 0 to 10% probability event), but merely an unremarkable coin toss. Then if I remark that (1-0.05)^14 = 0.487, which is a good approximation to 0.5, this gives me a 5% probability of breaking the current incarnation of the peg per year. For (2) I will use the "ineluctable course of history" hypothesis: the Chinese claim that they will be the best country ever in existence on the planet earth for 2049, the 100th anniversary of the PRC. Thus it would not make any sense to peg the HK currency to the dollar, the currency of a declining power. Notice how adorable they are: they make their projections with dart-throwing pandas, which are widely known to outperform dart-throwing chimps. Now, according to Tetlock's research, inevitable means about 80% probability. Using (1-0.056)^28 = 0.199, which the 0.199 the probability that the old peg will survive and 28 the number of years till the one country two systems expires,  this gives us a 5.6% probability of having a peg to the RMB per year. Summing (1) and (2) gives me a 10.6% of breakdown of the peg during the next year. If I notice that there are eight months, this gives me a 7%. Now, a few of the possible additions coming from the inside view are the following: (i) The original reason of the peg in 1983 was the uncertainty of the future of HK after the hangover. Sorry, I meant handover. This leaves (i.a) the peg is even more needed today than then, (i.b) maybe helmsman Xi will find this insulting, as everything in China is so much much better than in the west. (ii) The leadership of the HKMA (Hong Kong Monetary Authority) has recently changed, on the 1st of October. The new incumbent, Eddie Yue, has stated that there is no need to change the peg [1]. (iii) HK is used to move money from China to elsewhere. Now that capital controls are more and more strict by the day (getting money out of the country is a real pain), HK remains a loophole. The question is whether this is considered a bug or a feature by the communist party: should we avoid medium to high ranking officials to get their money out easily? or should that provoke too much of a backlash from within? (iv) The (apparently defunct) extradition bill was a close call, with a clear message of "get your money out of HK and go to Hongcouver to get a new passport, ASAP". The message might still be valid, and this might require some countermeasures. (v) The "Hong-Kong has no future" catchphrase has been part of Chinese propaganda since 2014. Being propaganda, it's probably only verborrhea. But who knows if they plan to do something with the excuse of the ongoing protests. I might try to integrate them into a more complete probability in future updates of this forecast. [1] https://www.scmp.com/business/banking-finance/article/3031307/hong-kongs-new-monetary-chief-eddie-yue-vows-defend

I have little understanding about finance so I'm more or less guessing. My synthesis has given me he below insight, which may be a wrong interpretation.  1. Even before the GFC, the HKD peg was maintained at 7.8
2. I think Hong Kong wants to keep their dollar under 7.851 but since Hong Kong trade has reduced (probably moving electronics production to Mainland China and the protest), this will probably drive up the HKD. 
3. I've chosen 40%, simple because I think the HKD wants to be within 7.8 but may not.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-currency-explainer-idUSKCN1VJ0WA

@KitsonJ states what I see as the most important points in this rationale: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/913983
I will go slightly higher for now because of the tense current situation.

The HKD has remained below HK$7.85100 since the currency peg was introduced in 1983. "The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the city’s de-facto central bank, buys local dollars if it gets too weak and sells to curb excessive strength. It has plenty of firepower, with $448.5 billion of assets in its foreign exchange fund alone as of July, representing roughly seven times the currency in circulation, according to HKMA." (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-currency-explainer-idUSKCN1VJ0WA)

Because of recent protests and disagreement with China, the overall future looks little dark. However, Hong Kong has very rigid economy that will not likely affected by much. From historical data, it looks little difficult to break the ceiling of $7.8510 at this point.
